Resting Heart Rate vs. Heart Rate During Exercise: What’s the Difference?

Dr. Mansi
October 15, 2024

Table of Contents

Have you ever thought about Resting Heart Rate vs. Heart Rate During Exercise. What’s the Difference? It’s fair to say that resting heart rate and exercise heart rate are some of the most significant metrics used for health and fitness monitoring. The difference between the two can make you know much more about your cardiovascular health or fitness levels.  A heart rate monitor can help you track these metrics effectively. So let’s understand this topic better by working out what resting heart rate and exercise heart rate are and their relevance in helping you on your fitness journey.

What is Resting Heart Rate?

Resting heart rate is the number of times your heart will beat in a minute while you are resting. It is typically measured first thing in the morning directly upon waking up but before you get out of bed. A heart rate monitor can help you track this effectively.For most adults, the normal range of RHR runs in the 60 to 100 beats per minute or bpm range.

A lower RHR typically means one is fitter and more efficient since less work is being done by the heart to circulate blood. The factors that would influence RHR include age, hydration, stress, and general fitness level, among others. Utilizing a heart rate monitor can help you keep track of these factors. This helps one monitor his or her fitness level better because if your RHR is on the lower side, then one would notice the improvements over time in his or her fitness levels. 

What is Heart Rate During Exercise?

This heart rate refers to the number of heartbeats per minute when you are performing some form of activity. A heart rate monitor is an effective tool for tracking this metric. This is a measure of the hard work your heart performs to oxygenate your muscles during exercise. Unlike resting heart rate, this heart rate varies with the intensity at which you exercise and the kind of exercise you do.

The Target Heart Rate for Maximum Physical Condition

The target heart rates for moderate and vigorous activities are shown in the table below, which is based on age and maximum heart rate.

The Differences Between Resting Heart Rate and Heart Rate During Exercise

  1. Measurement Conditions
    • Resting Heart Rate: measured while you are completely still, preferably right before you get out of bed in the morning, it can be done manually or with a heart rate monitor.
    • Heart Rate During Exercise: measured during workouts and representing your heart’s reaction to higher demands.
  2. Purpose and Significance
    • Resting Heart Rate: Shows your overall heart health and effectiveness. A lower RHR typically indicates higher fitness levels and improved recovery capacity.
    • Heart Rate During Exercise: This shows how hard you’re working out and how well your heart is delivering oxygen and blood to your muscles. It assists in modifying your exertion in order to reach fitness objectives.
  3. Normal Ranges
    • Resting Heart Rate: Usually falls between 60-100 beats per minute for adults, while athletes frequently exhibit slower rates.
    • Heart Rate During Exercise: The range can greatly differ depending on age, level of fitness, and intensity of exercise, typically hitting 70% to 85% of maximum heart rate during moderate to vigorous workouts.
  4. Response to Fitness Levels
    • Resting Heart Rate: A healthy heart will show a decreased RHR as it becomes more efficient with time.
    • Heart Rate During Exercise: People who are more fit may discover that they can work out at higher intensities while maintaining a lower heart rate, which is a sign of improved cardiovascular conditioning.

Does Exercising More Lower your Resting Heart Rate?

Yes, Engaging in daily exercise may reduce your resting heart rate in the long run. When you participate in aerobic exercises such as running or swimming, your heart improves its ability to pump blood effectively. This effectiveness enables your heart to pump more blood with each beat, leading to a decreased heart rate yet still providing enough oxygen and nutrients to your body while at rest.

When you engage in regular exercise to improve your cardiovascular fitness, your autonomic nervous system adapts and enhances parasympathetic activity, leading to relaxation and decreased heart rate. Athletes and people who frequently work out typically have resting heart rates that are lower than those of sedentary individuals. Nevertheless, individual reactions may differ, with age, physical condition, and general well-being also influencing the outcome.

The Benefits of Monitoring Your Heart Rate

  1. Better Training Efficiency: Understanding your heart rates allows you to customize your workouts for maximum performance, making sure you are exercising at the appropriate intensity to reach your objectives.
  2. Improvement in  Recovery: Keeping track of your resting heart rate can help you recognize times when you haven’t fully recovered, enabling you to modify your workouts to prevent overtraining and injury.
  3. Health Insights: Consistent observation can unveil trends that signal general heart health and aid in detecting possible problems at an early stage.
  4. Weight Management: Monitoring your heart rate can help with maximizing calorie burn and fat reduction, aiding in achieving your weight control objectives.
  5. Stress Management: Recognizing your heart rate can assist in identifying stress levels and using relaxation techniques as necessary.

Influencing Factors

Various factors, such as fitness level, age, and environmental conditions, can affect both resting heart rate and heart rate during exercise. Identifying these factors can assist people in customizing their workouts and enhancing their overall health.

Resting Heart Rate Influences:

  1. Fitness Level: Individuals who are more physically fit usually have a reduced resting heart rate.
  2. Age: Heart rate at rest typically rises as individuals get older.
  3. Medications: Some drugs, such as beta-blockers, have the ability to decrease heart rate.
  4. Stress and Emotions: Elevated resting heart rate can be caused by high levels of stress or anxiety.
  5. Sleep Quality: Inadequate sleep may result in an elevated resting heart rate.
  6. Hydration: Dehydration may result in an increase in heart rate.


Exercise Heart Rate Influences:

  1. Intensity of Exercise: Increased intensity results in an increased heart rate.
  2. Fitness Level: Higher levels of training can result in decreased heart rates while exercising at the same level of intensity.
  3. Temperature and Humidity: heart rate can be elevated during exercise caused by high temperatures and humidity
  4.  Nutrition: Consumption of food, particularly caffeine and sugar, has the potential to impact heart rate.
  5. Hydration Status: Sufficient hydration is important for an ideal heart rate response while exercising.

How to Measure RHR and Exercise Heart Rate

Measuring Resting Heart Rate

  • Best Time to Measure:
  •  Take your resting heart rate in the morning before rising from bed.
  • How to Measure:
    • Use a stopwatch or timer on your smartphone.
    • Locate your heartbeat on your wrist or neck and count the number of beats over a span of 60 seconds.


Measuring Exercise Heart Rate

  1. Using a Heart Rate Monitor:
    • Heart rate monitors like Wearable fitness trackers and chest straps offer immediate heart rate information.
  2. Manual Measurement:
    • While exercising, locate your pulse and tally for 15 seconds, then multiply the result by four to determine your beats per minute.

 

Monitoring both resting heart rate and exercise heart rate is essential for optimizing your fitness and health. Resting heart rate reflects your cardiovascular efficiency and recovery, while exercise heart rate indicates workout intensity and oxygen delivery to muscles. Regular tracking with a heart rate monitor empowers you to make informed fitness decisions and encourages continuous improvement. Embracing this knowledge can significantly impact your health journey.
